com.strongloop.android.loopback
Class UserRepository<U extends User>

java.lang.Object
  com.strongloop.android.remoting.Repository<T>
      com.strongloop.android.loopback.RestRepository<T>
          com.strongloop.android.loopback.ModelRepository<U>
              com.strongloop.android.loopback.UserRepository<U>

public class UserRepository<U extends User>
extends ModelRepository<U>

A base class implementing ModelRepository for the built-in User type. 

UserRepository<MyUser> userRepo = new UserRepository<MyUser>("user", MyUser.class);

Most application are extending the built-in User model and adds new properties like address, etc. You should create your own Repository class by extending this base class in such case. 

public class Customer extends User {
   // your custom properties and prototype (instance) methods
 }

 public class CustomerRepository extends UserRepository<Customer> {
     public interface LoginCallback extends LoginCallback<Customer> {
     }

     public CustomerRepository() {
         super("customer", null, Customer.class);
     }

     // your custom static methods
 }

UserRepository

public UserRepository(java.lang.String className,
                      java.lang.Class<U> userClass)
Creates a new UserRepository, associating it with the static U user class and the user class name.

Parameters:
className - The remote class name.
userClass - The User (sub)class. It must have a public no-argument constructor.

UserRepository

public UserRepository(java.lang.String className,
                      java.lang.String nameForRestUrl,
                      java.lang.Class<U> userClass)
Creates a new UserRepository, associating it with the static U user class and the user class name.

Parameters:
className - The remote class name.
nameForRestUrl - The pluralized class name to use in REST transport. Use null for the default value, which is the plural form of className.
userClass - The User (sub)class. It must have a public no-argument constructor.
Method Detail

getCurrentUserId

public java.lang.Object getCurrentUserId()
Returns:
Id of the currently logged in user. null when there is no user logged in.

setCurrentUserId

protected void setCurrentUserId(java.lang.Object currentUserId)

findCurrentUser

public void findCurrentUser(ObjectCallback<U> callback)
Fetch the data of the currently logged in user. Invokes callback.onSuccess(null) when no user is logged in. The data is cached, see getCachedCurrentUser()

Parameters:
callback - success/error callback

getCachedCurrentUser

public U getCachedCurrentUser()
Get the cached value of the currently logged in user. The value is updated by findCurrentUser(ObjectCallback), loginUser(String, String, LoginCallback) and logout(VoidCallback)

The typical usage:

  • At the application start up and after a successfull login, findCurrentUser(ObjectCallback) is called to pre-load the data.
  • All other places call getCachedCurrentUser() to access the data of the currently logged in user.

Returns:
The current user or null.

createContract

public RestContract createContract()
Creates a RestContract representing the user type's custom routes. Used to extend an Adapter to support user. Calls super ModelRepository createContract first.

Overrides:
createContract in class ModelRepository<U extends User>
Returns:
A RestContract for this model type.

loginUser

public void loginUser(java.lang.String email,
                      java.lang.String password,
                      UserRepository.LoginCallback<U> callback)
Login a user given an email and password. Creates a AccessToken and U user models if successful.

Parameters:
email - - user email
password - - user password
callback - - success/error callback

logout

public void logout(VoidCallback callback)
Logs the current user out of the server and removes the access token from the system.

Parameters:
callback - The callback to be executed when finished.
